body: @RNKuhns, can you kindly have a look at this, since you wrote the function/classes involved?
@eyalshafran and @fkiraly sorry for having missed this. Looking into it now.

I believe I've isolated what I think the issue being referenced is. 

Note that I don't get an error when executing `make_forecasting_scorer` to create a forecasting scorer or executing the returned scorer. The code snippet below runs as expected (returns 0.0) through that point. However, when trying to print the returned scorer, I'm seeing an error being raised.

```
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.performance_metrics.forecasting import mean_absolute_error, make_forecasting_scorer
y = load_airline()

mae = make_forecasting_scorer(mean_absolute_error, name="mae") # This works
print(mae(y, y)) # This works

print(mae) # This does not work
```

Based on the error message, I think the problem is that I've stored the input parameter `func` in the attribute `self._func`, when the expectation is it is stored in `self.func`. I believe we had it as `self.func` and then we made it non-public. 

I'm up for switching it back to `self.func` if that works for @fkiraly and @mloning. If so, I'll make that change after #1472 gets reviewed and merged.

Ah, yes, I should have spotted this!

`sklearn`'s pretty-print method (`__str__` or `__repr__`) assumes that arguments of the `__init__` are stored as an attribute of the same name - otherwise any printing will break, since it tries to access attributes of the same name as the `__init__` arguments that don't exist.

I think I wasn't involved in the discussion that led to renaming the parameter, but all descendants of `BaseObject` must obey the simple rule that `__init__` sets attributes with the same name as the inputs, just like `sklearn` estimators.

perhaps we should add a simple `BaseObject` extension template?
The other extension templates are very explicit about this rule.

and, we should probably add a test. Might be a good thing to add to `estimator_checks`.
I opened an issue here #1495

issue.title: [ENH] add test that checks correct hyper-parameter handling in __init__

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
`__init__` parameters of any class inheriting from `BaseObject` must be written to attributes of the same name in `__init__`, otherwise the class is no longer `sklearn` compatible, and `__repr__` or `__str__` will break, see #1422.

A test for this should be added to `estimator_checks`.

body: We originally had the `func` param stored in the `func` attribute, but then changed it later on. I can't remember why at this point. But I'm pushing a PR to fix this today.

issue.title: Fix Performance metric bug that affects repr

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:

you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request

Fixes #1422



#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

Stores the `func` param in the `func` attribute instead of the `_func` attribute. This ensure compliance with underlying expectation of sktime's `BaseObject`

-->
None.
